children.value: In this lecture we transfer the results about

children.html: LLL

children.value: to the projective hierarchy. The main idea is to relate sets of reals that are defined by set theoretic formulas to sets defined in second order arithmetic.
What is the complexity of the set

children.html: NN∩L\Baire \cap LNN∩L

children.value:
? In particular, is it in the projective hierarchy?
The set of all constructible reals is defined by a

children.html: Σ1\Sigma_1Σ1​

children.value: \varphi(x_0)	\; \equiv \; \exists y \; [y \text{ is an ordinal }  \; \wedge \; x_0 \in L_y \; \wedge \; x_0 \text{ is a set of natural numbers }  ].
children.html: φ(x0)  ≡  ∃y  [y is an ordinal   ∧  x0∈Ly  ∧  x0 is a set of natural numbers ].\varphi(x_0) \; \equiv \; \exists y \; [y \text{ is an ordinal } \; \wedge \; x_0 \in L_y \; \wedge \; x_0 \text{ is a set of natural numbers } ].φ(x0​)≡∃y[y is an ordinal ∧x0​∈Ly​∧x0​ is a set of natural numbers ].

children.value: We would like to replace this formula by an “equivalent” one in the language of second order arithmetic. In particular, we would like to replace the quantifier

children.html: ∃y\exists y∃y

children.value: by a quantifier over the reals.

children.value: formulas and then uses induction. Using Gödelization, one carefully defines all syntactical notions using arithmetic formulas. Then, one uses the recursive definition of truth to establish the definability of the satisfaction relation.
